definition: Guangyun, Chinese rime dictionary 韻書|韵书[yun4 shu1] from 11th century, containing 26,194 single-character entries
surname Guang
wide/numerous/to spread
the final (of a syllable) (Chinese phonology)/rhyme/appeal/charm/(literary) pleasant sound

sentences.english: Visitors will enter through the Guangyun Entrance which is located at the north-east part of the exposition site.
sentences.chinese: 遊客從位於展覽東北部的廣韻入口進入。

sentences.english: There are 17 sounds whose phonological positions in Wang-san are different from those in Guang-yun.
sentences.chinese: 《王三》中有17個小韻與《廣韻》音韻地位不同。

sentences.english: According to our statistics, Chen Li has cut 120 syllables from .
sentences.chinese: 據我們統計，陳澧共刪去了《廣韻》120個小韻。

definition: Jiyun, Chinese rime dictionary with 53,525 single-character entries, published in 11th century
see 說文解字|说文解字[Shuo1 wen2 Jie3 zi4]
Shuowen Jiezi, the original Han dynasty Chinese character dictionary with 10,516 entries, authored by Xu Shen 許慎|许慎[Xu3 Shen4] in 2nd century
sound and meaning
the four tones of Middle Chinese: level tone 平聲|平声, rising tone 上聲|上声, departing tone 去聲|去声 and entering tone 入聲|入声/the four tones of Modern Standard Mandarin
meaning of a character
ideogram plus phonetic (one of the Six Methods 六書|六书 of forming Chinese characters)/also known as phonogram, phonetic compound or picto-phonetic character
Xu Shen (-147) the compiler of the original Han dynasty dictionary Shuowen Jiezi 說文解字|说文解字[Shuo1 wen2 Jie3 zi4]
"Shiming", late Han dictionary, containing 1502 entries, using puns on the pronunciation of headwords to explain their meaning
Yang Xiong (53 BC-18 AD), scholar, poet and lexicographer, author of the first Chinese dialect dictionary 方言[Fang1 yan2]
falling tone/fourth tone in modern Mandarin
History of Zhou of the Northern Dynasties, twelfth of the 24 dynastic histories 二十四史[Er4 shi2 si4 Shi3], compiled under Linghu Defen 令狐德棻[Ling2 hu2 De2 fen1] in 636 during Tang Dynasty, 50 scrolls
phonetic component of a Chinese character
entering tone/checked tone/one of the four tones of Middle Chinese
Kong Yingda (574-648), Confucian scholar
Mr Gongyang's Annals or commentary on 春秋[Chun1 qiu1], early history, probably written by multiple authors during Han dynasty, same as 公羊春秋[Gong1 yang2 Chun1 qiu1]
